Combo Loss
The Combo Loss (Taghanaki et al., 2019) is a compound objective that combines a region-based
overlap term (Dice coefficient) with a pixel-wise classification term (weighted binary cross-
entropy, wBCE). It is particularly useful in scenarios where both small object segmentation and
pixel-wise accuracy are important.

Despite these advances, medical segmentation faces challenges related to data and task
structure. In many datasets, the region of interest (e.g., a lesion or vessel) constitutes only a
small portion of the image, while the background dominates. This imbalance biases standard
loss functions such as cross-entropy toward the majority class, resulting in poor detection of
small or rare structures (Sudre et al., 2017; Yeung et al., 2022). Because these underrepresented
regions often carry the greatest clinical significance, addressing imbalance is essential for robust
and fair segmentation.
Several loss functions have been proposed to address this issue, including cross-entropy
and Focal Loss (Lin et al., 2017), Dice and Tversky (Milletari et al., 2016; Salehi et al., 2017)
and extensions or combinations such as Focal Tversky, Combo Loss and the Unified Focal Loss
(Abraham and Khan, 2019; Taghanaki et al., 2019; Yeung et al., 2022).
